nodes.bodyText:
would be also good to add catch-all visitNode to avoid being ashamed by NPE next time
like 034a787#diff-e7b6201f06648c5aa2d66f8e488cde68R145-R150 ;)

You could use this example failing query to show that not every LATERAL on right of join means "correlated":
SELECT * FROM (VALUES 1) t(a), (SELECT * FROM LATERAL (SELECT a))
And a test with LATERAL in the context of aliased relation
SELECT * FROM LATERAL (VALUES 1) t(a)

not every LATERAL on right of join means "correlated":
SELECT * FROM (VALUES 1) t(a), (SELECT * FROM LATERAL (SELECT a))

That one is technically not on the right side of a join, since it's inside a subquery. In fact, it fails with "a cannot be resolved", as the column is not in the scope of the subquery.

That one is technically not on the right side of a join

Yes, I meant this example only for "documentational" reasons. Since we now support LATERAL in different contexts, it should be clear which contexts allow using correlated symbols and which don't. Precisely, that it is only possible if LATERAL is right of join, and not when LATERAL is contained inside right of join.
